required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 10, 2017
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Protocol for the Evaluation of Dario™ BGMS Performance at Elevated Altitude
clinical_study.official_title: Protocol for the Evaluation of Dario™ Blood Glucose Monitor (BGMS) Performance at Elevated Altitude

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the performance of the Dario Blood Glucose Monitor (BGMS), at elevated altitudes, by obtaining whole blood fingerstick samples from individuals and analyzing the blood on the Dario Blood Glucose Monitor (BGMS) and comparing the readings to readings obtained from the YSI 2300 STAT Plus glucose analyzer.

detailed_description.textblock: The study will be performed with 50 fresh capillary blood samples, collected by fingerstick using Dario single use lancet. Additional fingerstick with dedicated disposable lancets will be used to collect sufficient capillary fresh blood to be analyzed by the YSI 2300 STAT Plus analyzer. Additional fingersticks may be necessary if volume of blood from first fingerstick is insufficient.

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of the Dario™ Blood Glucose Monitor (BGMS) at elevated altitude by comparing the blood glucose level (BGL) results measured by Dario™ BGMS vs. BGL results measured by YSI

arm_group.description: Blood obtained via fingerstick and blood glucose level is tested on the Dario Blood Glucose Monitoring System
Blood obtained via fingerstick and blood glucose level is tested on the YSI STAT for comparison to the results obtained with the Dario Blood Glucose Monitoring System

intervention.description: Fingerstick to obtain blood sample for analysis with the Dario BGMS
Fingerstick to obtain blood sample for analysis with YSI

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age of subject is 18 years or older
- Able to speak and read English
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant
- Has any condition that the principal investigator believes may interfere in the subject's participation in the trial.
